Problem:
Consider a complex function \\(z(t) = u(t) + iv(t)\\) where \\(u(t)\\) and \\(v(t)\\) are real functions of time describing a signal in the complex plane. The Fourier transform \\(\\mathcal{F}\\{z(t)\\}(\\omega) = Z(\\omega)\\) converts this time-domain signal into the frequency domain. Analyze the causal impacts of a phase shift transformation \\( h(z) = e^{i\\theta}z \\) applied to the signal.

Can we determine the exact angle of phase shift \\(\\theta\\) in the transformation \\( h(z) \\) by observing the Fourier transform \\( Z(\\omega) \\)?
Explanation: The phase shift introduced by \\( h(z) \\) directly corresponds to a uniform shift in the phase spectrum of the Fourier transform \\( Z(\\omega) \\). By analyzing the phase spectrum, the angle \\(\\theta\\) can be exactly determined, showing a definitive causal inference from effect to specific cause.
